text: I stay where I am, no longer pushing forward.
I don’t touch her battlefield—I only do the work she said ‘wouldn’t get in the way’: hauling supplies, passing medicine, running errands, dragging the fallen back behind the line.
The snow falls thicker and thicker. Mud and ice churn underfoot, every step like plunging into cold water. But the people at the North Gate don’t stop.

The moment the medicine chest is opened, the sharp scent of disinfectant overwhelms the smell of blood. Lucia crouches in a makeshift shelter, her fingers red from the cold, still wrapping bandages tight, loop after loop.
She looks up and sees me—relief flickers in her eyes for a split second, then tightens again.
“You actually stayed…”
“I’m just moving supplies. I won’t go forward.”
“Then take these to the left shield line, behind the formation.”
She stuffs a pouch of clotting powder into my arms, moving fast—like if she slows down, she might start thinking too much.

I run past the temporary supply piles and see a different kind of struggle: someone bracing crates with their shoulder, someone retying ropes stiff with ice, someone shielding the wounded from the wind with torn blankets.
No one shouts about heroes—only short, urgent calls of “Here,” “More,” “Hurry.”
From a distance, I see Alicia standing on the stone steps. She makes no unnecessary movements, yet holds the entire line together.
She points to the left wing and shields fill the gap at once; she raises a hand and the archers on the right reposition. Not a single word wasted.
That kind of proficiency isn’t ease—it’s fear compressed to its thinnest layer, so thin it becomes invisible.
I hand the medicine to a guard, turn back toward her, and can’t help calling out, “Alicia!”
She looks at me, her gaze flicking first to the medicine pouch in my hands, then to my position on the ground—confirming I haven’t crossed the line.
“You’re doing the right thing.”
“I’m not getting in the way.”
“You already are—in my head.”
She says it plainly, briefly—like she’s holding her emotions down and only allowing herself this much.
“Go back.”
“It hasn’t started yet—”
“It will.”
“I need you to hold the inn. Keep the fire lit. Bolt the door. If Lucia comes back, give her hot water.”
When she says the words “hot water,” her tone softens just a little—like she’s finally allowing herself to admit that someone will be afraid, will be cold, will reach their limit.
“Will you come back?”
She doesn’t hesitate.
“I’ll try.”
Not a promise—just all the honesty she can give.
She lifts a hand and gestures me backward, placing me back into a ‘safe position.’ Then she turns to resume her deployment, her back clean and taut, like a bow drawn to full tension.
I stand there and realize my palms are slick with sweat. When the wind hits, the cold stings.
I leave the North Gate as she told me to. I keep looking back, watching the defensive line in the snow and fog tighten into a single stretched black thread.
When I return to the inn, the fire is still burning—but I can’t sit still.
That night, I don’t sleep. Every time the wind grows louder, I think it’s starting at the North Gate.
